articles.headline: For Wal-Mart, a Christmas That’s Made to Order
articles.snippet: Even as financial turmoil has cut into sales at many stores, it sent consumers into the arms of Wal-Mart.
articles.abstract: Even as financial turmoil has cut into sales at many stores, it sent consumers into the arms of Wal-Mart.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation has two kinds of retailers these days: those bracing for a grim holiday season, and Wal-Mart.

articles.headline: A Towering Economic To-Do List for Obama
articles.snippet: A look at some of the crucial issues that will test the new administration, and how it might address them.
articles.abstract: A look at some of the crucial issues that will test the new administration, and how it might address them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dismal state of the economy helped decide Tuesday’s presidential election. And it almost certainly will dominate the early days of the Obama administration.

articles.headline: Bans in 3 States on Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: The losses in California, Arizona and Florida devastated supporters of same-sex marriage.
articles.abstract: The losses in California, Arizona and Florida devastated supporters of same-sex marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A giant rainbow-colored flag in the gay-friendly Castro neighborhood of San Francisco was flying at half-staff on Wednesday as social and religious conservatives celebrated the passage of measures that ban same-sex marriage in California, Florida and Arizona.
articles.byline: By Jesse McKinley and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: For Obama, No Time to Bask in Victory As He Starts to Build a Transition Team
articles.snippet: President-elect Barack Obama prepared to name an ally as his White House chief of staff in his first step toward assuming power.
articles.abstract: President-elect Barack Obama prepared to name an ally as his White House chief of staff in his first step toward assuming power.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Barack Obama began moving Wednesday to build his administration and make good on his ambitious promises to point the United States in a different direction, as his commanding victory reordered the American political landscape and transfixed much of the nation and the world.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Top Priority Is Stabilizing the Patient
articles.snippet: The new administration’s top priority should be to put in place emergency plans for the financial markets and the broader economy.
articles.abstract: The new administration’s top priority should be to put in place emergency plans for the financial markets and the broader economy.

articles.headline: Striking a Balance While Becoming a First Family
articles.snippet: Friends say the Obamas are acutely aware that everything they do will brim with symbolic value.
articles.abstract: Friends say the Obamas are acutely aware that everything they do will brim with symbolic value.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Verna Williams called to congratulate Michelle Obama on Wednesday morning, she half-jokingly offered to stop calling her old law school buddy “Meesh” and start calling her something more dignified.

articles.headline: Democrats in Congress Vowing to Pursue an Aggressive Agenda
articles.snippet: Congressional leaders promised to make priorities of the economy, health care, energy and ending the Iraq war.
articles.abstract: Congressional leaders promised to make priorities of the economy, health care, energy and ending the Iraq war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Flush with victory built on incursions in the South and West, Congressional Democratic leaders promised to use their new power to join President-elect Barack Obama in pursuing an aggressive agenda that puts top priority on the economy, health care, energy and ending the Iraq war.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: A Once-United G.O.P. Emerges, in Identity Crisis
articles.snippet: A coalition once notable for its disciplined unity is now threatened by sectarian rifts that could widen in the weeks ahead.
articles.abstract: A coalition once notable for its disciplined unity is now threatened by sectarian rifts that could widen in the weeks ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: One by one, prized Republican strongholds fell Tuesday night and yesterday. Ohio and Indiana, Florida and Virginia, Colorado and Nevada — all succumbed to Senator Barack Obama. And for conservatives it was as disorienting a day as any in the history of the movement that has been a dominant force in shaping modern American politics.

articles.headline: Wall Street’s Pay Is Expected to Plummet
articles.snippet: The first clues are emerging that Wall Street pay will plummet this year — but perhaps not enough to satisfy the financial industry’s critics.
articles.abstract: The first clues are emerging that Wall Street pay will plummet this year — but perhaps not enough to satisfy the financial industry’s critics.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first clues are emerging that Wall Street pay will plummet this year  but perhaps not enough to satisfy the financial industry’s critics.

articles.headline: Bleak Reports Keep Markets in Free Fall
articles.snippet: Stocks slumped amid a poor outlook for the retail and automobile industries and worries about the state of the labor market.
articles.abstract: Stocks slumped amid a poor outlook for the retail and automobile industries and worries about the state of the labor market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The political world shifted on Tuesday, but the change did little to ease the anxiety on Wall Street.

articles.headline: European Banks Reduce Rates, Some Sharply
articles.snippet: The European Central Bank reduced its benchmark rate by a half percentage point, while the Bank of England cut rates by a startling 1.5 percentage points.
articles.abstract: The European Central Bank reduced its benchmark rate by a half percentage point, while the Bank of England cut rates by a startling 1.5 percentage points.
articles.lead_paragraph: The top three European central banks cut interest rates Thursday in the face of increasingly dire evidence that much of Europe was moving into a serious recession.
articles.byline: By Carter Dougherty and Julia Werdigier
